    What does T(n) mean in relation to O(n)?

    When discussing an algorithm, the common usage of the symbol ğ‘‡T is to represent its time complexity. ğ‘‡T is a function. The input to this function is the input size, the output is the (worst-case) running time for an input of that size. Therefore, ğ‘‡(ğ‘›)T(n) is a number: the number returned by the function ğ‘‡T when given the number ğ‘›n. This number is the running time of our algorithm on an input of size ğ‘›n. The ğ‘‚O in â€œğ‘‚(ğ‘›)O(n)â€ is not a function. This is Big O notation. In particular, the symbol ğ‘‚(ğ‘›)O(n) represents the class of all functions that grow (asymptotically) at most as quickly as the linear function ğ‘“(ğ‘›)=ğ‘›f(n)=n. Big O notation gives us a convenient way to talk about upper bounds. For example, we can say â€œthe time complexity of this algorithm is ğ‘‚(ğ‘›2)O(n2)â€ (formally: â€œğ‘‡âˆˆğ‘‚(ğ‘›2)TâˆˆO(n2)â€) to say that the running time of the algorithm is at most quadratic in the input size. Sometimes, you can see both symbols being used in a single equation. For example, the time complexity of MergeSort is commonly described by the following recurrence: â€œğ‘‡(ğ‘›)=2ğ‘‡(ğ‘›/2)+ğ‘‚(ğ‘›)T(n)=2T(n/2)+O(n)â€. The meaning of the above statement: For any ğ‘›n, the time ğ‘‡(ğ‘›)T(n) needed to sort ğ‘›n elements can be computed by taking the time ğ‘‡(ğ‘›/2)T(n/2) needed to sort ğ‘›/2n/2 elements, multiplying that time by 2, and adding something extra. That something extra must be at most linear in ğ‘›n.

    What does T(n) mean in relation to O(n)? - Quora

    Big O í‘œê¸°ë²•ì€ ìš°ë¦¬ì—ê²Œ ìƒìœ„ì— ëŒ€í•´ ì´ì•¼ê¸°í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆëŠ” í¸ë¦¬í•œ ë°©ë²•ì„ ì œê³µí•œë‹¤. ì˜ˆë¥¼ ë“¤ì–´, ìš°ë¦¬ëŠ” â€œì´ ì•Œê³ ë¦¬ì¦˜ì˜ ì‹œê°„ ë³µì¡ì„±ì€ O(n2)â€(ê³µì‹ì ìœ¼ë¡œ â€œTOO(n2))ë¼ê³  ë§í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆë‹¤.

    ë•Œë•Œë¡œ, ë‹¹ì‹ ì€ í•˜ë‚˜ì˜ ë°©ì •ì‹ì— ë‘ ê°œì˜ ê¸°í˜¸ê°€ ì‚¬ìš©ë˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì„ ë³¼ ìˆ˜ ìˆë‹¤. ì˜ˆë¥¼ ë“¤ì–´, MergeSortì˜ ì‹œê°„ ë³µì¡ì„±ì€ ì¼ë°˜ì ìœ¼ë¡œ â€œT(n)=2T(n/2)+O(n)â€ì— ì˜í•´ ì„¤ëª…ëœë‹¤.
